titlestmt.title: Europe a Prophecy Copy MPI : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: XML file approx. 800KB; 82 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 150KB to 1700KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesOctober 2022
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of forty-one proofs, impressions in different states, posthumous impressions, and lifetime impressions of Europe a Prophecy.
These loose impressions are referred to in the index of copies as "MPI," an abbreviation for Miscellaneous Plates and Impressions. As a group, MPIs reveal Blake's creative process as it unfolded through production, providing insights and new information about designs and texts. For example, six plates are in early states not used in published copies. Object 16 is an impression of Plate 5 in the first of two states; Objects 13, 22, and 38 are impressions of Plates 4, 9, and 17 in the first of three states; and Objects 39 and 40 are impressions of Plates 17 and 18 in the second of three states. Objects 10 and 11, impressions of Plate 2, have major motifs added by Blake in pencil, pen and ink, and gray washes. Object 5, an impression of Plate 1, the frontispiece of the “Ancient of Days,” is from the Whitworth Gallery and is in Blake’s late coloring style. Object 4, an impression of Plate 1, was printed by Blake but colored by an unknown hand. The same is true of Objects 19 and 20, impressions of Plates 6 and 7, which were trimmed of most of their texts, as were Objects 12, 18, and 21, impressions of Plates 4, 6, and 7.
Object 1, another impression of Plate 1, was lightly color printed by Blake; the colorist of the black wash forming the clouds, however, is questionable. Object 12, an impression of Plate 4, was color printed. Object 29, an impression of Plate 11, was heavily color printed, probably as the first pull of the plate color printed for Europe Copy B, which is in the Archive. Objects 25 and 32, impressions of Plates 10 and 12, were lightly color printed, with the latter finished in delicate washes. Objects 14, 17, 23, and 41, impressions of Plates 4, 5, 9, and 18, are posthumous, printed by Frederick Tatham, who printed Europe Copy M, c. 1832, which is in the Archive, in this reddish brown color.
Europe Copy MPI can be accessed like plates in copies of Europe and compared with impressions from the same copperplate using the "Objects from the Same Matrix" feature in the second navigation bar below the image. The Archive will gradually publish groups of miscellaneous plates and impressions for each illuminated book, which will enable users to trace the evolution of Blake's printed designs.
The Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable digital editions of 123 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books. Users may view color corrected digital images of Blake's works at their true size, and enlarge and rotate these images to examine texts and illustrations in detail. The images are accompanied by diplomatic transcriptions and editors' notes, as well as illustration descriptions that make it possible to search Blake's works for visual motifs. The Archive also provides full bibliographic and provenance information for each digital edition it publishes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.numberleaves: 32Objects 13/16 (Bentley Plates 4/5), 15/26 (Bentley Plates 5/10), 18/21 (Bentley Plates 6/7), 19/20 (Bentley Plates 6/7), 27/38 (Bentley Plates 11/17), 30/31 (Bentley Plates 11/12), 33/35 (Bentley Plates 13/14), 34/36 (Bentley Plates 13/14), and 37/39 (Bentley Plates 16/17) are printed recto/verso. The printing of Objects 27 and 38 (Bentley Plates 11 and 17) recto/verso, also found in proof Copy a, may indicate an early version of *Europe* with a plate sequence in which Plate 17 follows Plate 11. A. W. J. Lincoln, "Blake's 'Europe': An Early Version?," *Notes and Queries* n.s. 25.3 (1978): 213, suggests that proof Copy a is this early version. For further discussion see Alexander S. Gourlay, "Philip D. Sherman's Blakes at Brown University," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 28.3 (winter 1994-95): 94-99.

objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etchingObjects 1, 12, 25, 29, and 32 include color printing. Objects 1, 4, 5, 12, 19, 20, 29, 32, 33, and 35 include hand coloring with water colors. The hand coloring on Objects 4, 19, and 20 is not by Blake. The black coloring on some of the clouds in Object 1 may have been added by an unknown hand. Objects 10 and 11 include motifs added by Blake in pencil, pen and ink, and gray wash.
objinfo.inkcolor: orange-brown and blue-green (Object 1), blue or blue-green (Objects 2, 12, 15, 21, 26, 32, 36), dark blue (Object 3), reddish-brown (Objects 4, 6, 7), yellow ochre (Object 5), black (Objects 8-11, 16, 24), grayish green (Objects 13, 18, 19, 22, 27, 30, 31, 33-35, 37, 39, 40), brick red (Objects 14, 17, 23, 41), grayish blue (Objects 20, 29, 38), black, reddish brown, yellow ochre, and possibly greenish blue (Object 25), brownish black (Object 28)There is a wide range of blue, green, and gray ink colors that appear to be different shades under different lighting conditions.
objinfo.pennednumbers: Object 39 is numbered "10" top right, possibly by Blake.
objinfo.framelines: Object 29 includes 2 framing lines, the inner one contiguous with the edges of the plate. Object 32 includes 1 framing line contiguous with the edges of the image.
objinfo.binding: Objects 40 and 41 are bound with nine impressions of eight plates from *Jerusalem* in dark blue morocco. No other objects are currently bound.

provenance.name: Multiple
provenance.note: Object 1 (Bentley Plate 1): Possibly acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts; William Bell Scott by 1876; sold from Scott's collection, Sotheby's, 14 July 1892, lot 177 (£5.10s. to Robert Ross for Carfax & Co.); Sydney Morse by 1904; sold from Morse's collection, Christie's, 26 July 1929, lot 20 (£315 to Colnaghi & Co.); acquired Feb. 1930 by the dealer Charles Sessler ($1534); sold March 1930 to Lessling J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1943.

Object 2 (Bentley Plate 1): Probably inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; acquired by George A. Smith and bound by him in "about 1853" (Bentley page 337) with other works by Blake, including the manuscript "Order" of the *Songs of Innocence and of Experience*; the volume offered, presumably by Smith, at a Puttick and Simpson auction, London, 3-4 July 1863, no lot number recorded (£15.15s., possibly bought-in by Smith given the reappearance of the volume in the Smith auction of 1880); the volume offered by the dealer Bernard Quaritch, 1864 *Catalogue of Books*, item 6521, possibly on consignment from, or in partnership with, Smith (£21); the volume sold by Smith, Christie's, 1 April 1880, lot 168 (£66 to Quaritch); the volume apparently lent by Quaritch to William Muir, who used some works as the basis for his facsimiles; the volume offered by Quaritch, Oct. 1883 *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts*, item 10,252 (£80), May 1885 catalogue, *William Blake's Original Drawings*, page 2, no item number (£80), and 1887 *General Catalogue of Books*, volume 2, item 10,252 (£80); the volume acquired by Bernard Buchanan Macgeorge between 1892 and 1906; the volume sold from the Macgeorge collection, Sotheby's, 1 July 1924, lot 133 (£345 to the dealer E. Parsons & Sons); the volume, possibly with some leaves removed, offered by Maggs Bros., 1924 catalogue 456, item 53 (£630); the volume acquired no later than 1927 by George C. Smith who disbound the volume; this print sold from George C. Smith's collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, in lot 29 with Objects 14 and 17 (Plates 4 and 5) of *Europe* ($245 to the dealer Charles Sessler acting for Moncure Biddle); this impression only on consignment with Sessler from the Biddle collection by March 1957; acquired March 1957 by "Dan[s?] Grubb" (according to Sessler's records); with Sessler's again in Feb. 1964; sold by Sessler June 1964 to Leonard Baskin ($175); sold May 1997 by Baskin (through his son, Josiah Baskin) to the dealer John Windle acting for Robert N. Essick ($75,000).

Object 3 (Bentley Plate 1): Early history unknown; acquired at an unknown time by the Earl of Crewe; sold from Crewe's collection, Sotheby's, 30 March 1903, in lot 18 with seven other etchings and engravings by Blake including an unidentified plate from *Europe* (£10 to the dealer James Tregaskis, possibly acting for E. J. Shaw); this print sold from Shaw's collection, Sotheby's, 29 July 1925, in lot 157 with five other etchings and engravings by Blake (£31 to Geoffrey Keynes); bequeathed to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes's death in 1982, on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum; given by the Trust to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 2018.

Object 4 (Bentley Plate 1): Possibly Frederick Tatham; William A. White by no later than 1905; sold from White's collection c. 1929 to A. S. W. Rosenbach; bequeathed by Rosenbach to the Rosenbach Museum and Library in 1952 and accessioned by the Rosenbach in 1954.

Object 5 (Bentley Plate 1): Probably acquired from Blake in 1827 by Frederick Tatham (for "three guineas and a half" according to J. T. Smith; see Bentley, *Records*, page 620); possibly George Blamire, the impression sold from his collection, Christie's, 9 Nov. 1863, lot 120, with another work by Blake, possibly Butlin 299, *Naomi Entreating Ruth and Orpah to Return to the Land of Moab*, both described as "Drawings—*in colours*" (£5.7s.6d. to "Halsted," probably a dealer); J. E. Taylor no later than 1876; given by Taylor to the Whitworth Art Gallery in 1892.

Object 6 (Bentley Plate 1): Early history unknown; possibly the impression lent to the Burlington Fine Arts Club in 1876 by A. Macmillan; William A. White no later than 1905; sold from White's collection to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach in 1929; sold by Rosenbach in Nov. 1952 to Hannah D. Rabinowitz; sold to, or on consignment with, the dealer C. A. Stonehill no later than 1970; sold by Stonehill to Paul Mellon in 1970; given by Mellon to the Yale Center for British Art in 1992.

Object 7 (Bentley Plate 2): As for Object 2 to 1938; sold from the George C. Smith collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 27, with an impression of *Jerusalem* Plate 8 on the verso ($150 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1943.

Object 8 (Bentley Plate 2): Early history unknown; probably William Bell Scott by no later than 1885; probably the impression sold from Scott's collection, Sotheby's, 21 April 1885, lot 165, the verso impression of *Jerusalem* Plate 1 wrongly described as a "Proof of a Plate which afterwards served for the first Print in America" (11s. to "Fawcett," probably a dealer); Mrs. Graham Smith; her nephew, Anthony Asquith; sold through Hodgson's (dealer and auctioneer) in 1942 to Geoffrey Keynes; bequeathed to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes's death in 1982, on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum; given by the Trust to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 2018.

Object 9 (Bentley Plate 2): Bound in the late 19th century into a volume of works by and about Blake; W. H. Herriman; bequeathed by Herriman in 1920 to the American Academy in Rome; sold by the Academy in 1976 to the Pierpont Morgan Library (now the Morgan Library and Museum).
Object 10 (Bentley Plate 2): As for Object 9.

Object 11 (Bentley Plate 2): Acquired at an unknown time by Robert Arthington and sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 17 May 1866, lot 24, bound in calf with forty-eight drawings, etchings, and engravings by Blake, including Objects 13, 16, 22, 28, 37, and 39 (£11 to "Pickering," probably the dealer B. M. Pickering); possibly William Fuller-Maitland until his death in 1876; the volume sold Christie's, 1 June 1887, lot 258 (£34 to Henry White); the volume sold from White's collection, Sotheby's, 22 April 1902, lot 270 (£87 to "Roberts," probably a dealer); the volume sold Sotheby's, 9 Dec. 1905, lot 921 (£80 to "Paul," probably a dealer); the volume sold Sotheby's, 15 Dec. 1906, lot 482 (£155 to the dealer "Abbey" acting for the Pierpont Morgan Library, now the Morgan Library and Museum); the leaves disbound and mounted by the Morgan Library and Museum.

Object 12 (Bentley Plate 4): Acquired at an unknown time by George Richmond, possibly directly from Blake or his wife Catherine; given by George Richmond to his son, John Richmond, 19 March 1890; Mrs. John Richmond, who sold this impression to Geoffrey Keynes in 1927; bequeathed to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes's death in 1982 and placed on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum; given 2018 by the Keynes Trust to the Fitzwilliam Museum.
Object 13 (Bentley Plate 4): As for Object 11. Object 16 (Bentley Plate 5) is printed on the verso.

Object 14 (Bentley Plate 4): Printed by Frederick Tatham c. 1832; then as for Object 2 through the sale to Sessler on behalf of Moncure Biddle at the Smith auction of 2 Nov. 1938, lot 29; with Object 17 (Plate 5) with Sessler's again, probably no later than 1957; sold with Object 17 to Leonard Baskin, probably in June 1964; acquired with Object 17 by Haven O'More for The Garden Ltd. (a collection formed by Michael Davis); sold from the collection of The Garden Ltd., Sotheby's, 10 Nov. 1989, lot 167, with Object 17 ($17,600 to Donald Heald acting for Robert N. Essick).

Object 15 (Bentley Plate 5): Early history unknown; acquired at an unknown time by the Earl of Crewe; the dealer James Tregaskis; acquired by W. Graham Robertson in 1904; sold from the Robertson collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 86 (£10.10s. to "Gain," a dealer acting for Geoffrey Keynes); bequeathed to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes's death in 1982 and placed on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum; given to the Fitzwilliam Museum by the estate of Mary Cecilia Keynes in 2020 and accessioned by the Fitzwilliam Museum in 2020. The provenance record through Robertson's acquisition in 1904 is based on *The Blake Collection of W. Graham Robertson*, ed. Kerrison Preston (London: Faber and Faber, 1952) 251. Object 26 (Bentley Plate 10) is printed on the verso.
Object 16 (Bentley Plate 5): As for Object 11. Object 13 (Bentley Plate 4) is printed on the recto.
Object 17 (Bentley Plate 5): As for Object 14.

Object 18 (Bentley Plate 6): Possibly William A. White by no later than 1905; Gould Weston; sold from the Weston collection, Christie's, 15 July 1957, lot 28 (£26.5s. to the Leger Gallery); the dealer John Fleming, who gave the work to Geoffrey Keynes shortly after the 1957 auction; bequeathed to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes's death in 1982 and placed on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum; given to the Fitzwilliam Museum by the estate of Stephen Keynes in 2020 and accessioned by the Fitzwilliam Museum in 2020. Object 21 (Bentley Plate 7) is printed on the verso. Fleming gave this leaf to Keynes in "1956" according to *Bibliotheca Bibliographici: A Catalogue of the Library Formed by Geoffrey Keynes* (London: Trianon Press, 1964) 57, but this is probably an error since the gift must have been made after the 1957 auction.

Object 19 (Bentley Plate 6): Possibly inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon her husband's death in 1827; possibly acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; George Richmond; sold from Richmond's collection, Christie's, 29 April 1897, lot 147 with 21 other works by Blake (£2.10s. to Richard Sisley); his daughter, Mrs. John Richmond; acquired from Mrs. Richmond by the Tate Gallery (now Tate collection) in 1922. Object 20 (Bentley Plate 7) is printed on the verso.
Object 20 (Bentley Plate 7): As for Object 19 (Bentley Plate 6), printed on the recto.
Object 21 (Bentley Plate 7): As for Object 18 (Bentley Plate 6), printed on the recto.
Object 22 (Bentley Plate 9): As for Object 11.

Object 23 (Bentley Plate 9): Printed by Frederick Tatham c. 1832; then as for Object 2 to 1938; sold from the George C. Smith collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 31, with Objects 24 (Plate 10 with an impression of *Europe* Plate 5 on the recto), 30 (Plate 11), and 31 (Plate 12) ($280 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1943.
Object 24 (Bentley Plate 10): As for Object 23. An impression of *Europe* Plate 5 is printed on the recto.

Object 25 (Bentley Plate 10): Possibly the impression offered by the dealer Francis Harvey, c. 1864, for 10s; possibly bound with 144 other Blake prints and drawings in an extra-illustrated copy of Alexander Gilchrist's *Life of William Blake* (1863); the volume offered by John Pearson, catalogue 58 of c. 1884, item 363 (£52.10s.); this impression only acquired by J[?] Iden. Hart; sold by Hart to the British Museum on 2 Oct. 1936.
Object 26 (Bentley Plate 10): As for Object 15, printed on the recto.

Object 27 (Bentley Plate 11): Early history unknown; offered in Weyhe Gallery Dec. 1938 catalogue 81, item 125 ($125); "bought from Allen of New York about 1964 by Mr. Charles Ryskamp" (Bentley page 341); placed on consignment by Ryskamp with the dealer Nicholas W. Lott no later than June 1994; acquired July 1994 from Lott by Robert N. Essick ($25,000). Object 38 (Bentley Plate 17) is printed on the verso. For information on the provenance of this impression and its relationship to the impressions of Plates 11 and 17 (also printed recto/verso) at Brown University, with which this impression is sometimes confused, see Alexander S. Gourlay, "Philip D. Sherman's Blake's at Brown University," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 28.3 (winter 1994/95): 95-98.
Object 28 (Bentley Plate 11): As for Object 11. An impression of *Europe* Plate 17 is printed on the verso.

Object 29 (Bentley Plate 11): "Perhaps this is the 'design' [John] Linnell bought [from Blake] for £1.1*s*. in Aug 1821" (Bentley page 163); Linnell by no later than 1876; sold from Linnell's collection, Christie's, 15 March 1918, lot 178 (£97.5s. to the Felton Bequest acting for the National Gallery of Victoria); received by the National Gallery of Victoria on 13 March 1920.
Object 30 (Bentley Plate 11): As for Object 23. Object 31 (Bentley Plate 12) is printed on the verso.
Object 31 (Bentley Plate 12): As for Object 23. Object 30 (Bentley Plate 11) is printed on the recto.

Object 32 (Bentley Plate 12): Early history unknown; Greville MacDonald by no later than 1914; the dealer Francis Edwards; sold by Edwards to Geoffrey Keynes in 1928; bequeathed to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes's death in 1982 and placed on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum.

Object 33 (Bentley Plate 13): Early history unknown; sold from an anonymous private collection, Christie's, 18 Dec. 2001, lot 85, with Object 35 on the verso (£30,550 to Maggs Bros. acting for Robert N. Essick).

Object 34 (Bentley Plate 13): As for Object 2 to 1938; sold from the George C. Smith Collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 32, with Object 36 printed on the verso and with impressions of *Europe* Plates 11/17 printed recto/verso (now at Brown University) and an untraced impression of *Europe* Plate 15 ($160 to the dealer E. Weyhe); possibly an anonymous private collector; acquired by the Print Club of Philadelphia; deposited in 1955 in the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
Object 35 (Bentley Plate 14): As for Object 33, printed on the recto.
Object 36 (Bentley Plate 14): As for Object 34, printed on the recto.
Object 37 (Bentley Plate 16): As for Object 11. Object 39 (Bentley Plate 17) is printed on the verso.
Object 38 (Bentley Plate 17): As for Object 27 (Bentley Plate 11) printed on the recto.
Object 39 (Bentley Plate 17): As for Object 11. Object 37 (Bentley Plate 16) is printed on the recto.

Object 40 (Bentley Plate 18): As for Object 2 to 1938; sold from the George C. Smith Collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 40, with Object 41 and bound with 9 impressions of 8 plates from *Jerusalem* ($500 to A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1943.
Object 41 (Bentley Plate 18): As for Object 40.

desc.objtitle: Europe a Prophecy The Ancient of Days, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state (of two). The black coloring on some of the clouds may have been added by an unknown hand. William Bell Scott's small collection mark appears in the lower left margin.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old, nude, but muscular man with long hair and beard squats within a circle, perhaps meant to represent the disc of the sun. His hair and beard extend horizontally to the left, as though blown by a strong wind from right to left. His left leg is bent at the knee, with both left knee and left foot prominent. His right leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back, knee touching the edge of the circle. He is hunched over and looks down or has his eyes closed; his left arm is extended down. He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. Slight indications of a robe or some sort of drapery appear just right of the figure's left foot. Beams of light emanate from the circle, surrounded by clouds except where the man's arm extends downward. The dramatic shading on the clouds and the bright light behind the figure suggest either sunrise or sunset or, alternatively, the sky after a storm. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."

The figure and the disc in which he squats are surrounded by dark clouds except where his left arm descends. The dramatic shading on the clouds and the bright light behind the figure suggest either sunrise or sunset or, alternatively, the sky after a storm.
The horizontal position of the figure's hair and beard suggests a strong wind blowing from right to left.

desc.objtitle: Europe a Prophecy The Ancient of Days, Object 5 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

objnote.p: Butlin 271 records the inscription center right as "Blake 1824 [?, or clumsy 'inv'—end smudged]." Bentley page 109, "Ancient of Days" Copy F, records the inscription as "Blake 1827." This impression has often been identified as the one Blake richly colored shortly before his death in 1827; see the accounts by J. T. Smith and Frederick Tatham in Bentley, *Records*, pages 620-21 (Smith) and 682 (Tatham). The printing date of the underlying relief-etched image is probably 1794 when Blake was printing many plates for *Europe*. The state of the plate cannot be determined with any certainty, because of the rich hand coloring that obscures most of the underlying printed image, but it is probably in the second state (of two).

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old, nude, but muscular man with long hair and beard squats within a circle, perhaps meant to represent the disc of the sun. His hair and beard extend horizontally to the left, as though blown by a strong wind from right to left. His left leg is bent at the knee, with both left knee and left foot prominent. His right leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back, knee touching the edge of the circle. He is hunched over and looks down or has his eyes closed; his left arm is extended down. He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. Slight indications of a robe or some sort of drapery appear just right of the figure's left foot. Distinct rays of light appear to emanate from behind the lower half of the disc; the sky behind the top half is suffused with light. The disc is surrounded by clouds except where the man's arm extends downwards. The dramatic shading on the clouds and the bright light behind the figure suggest either sunrise or sunset or, alternatively, the sky after a storm. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."

He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. A robe or some sort of drapery appears just right of the figure's left foot. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."

The figure kneels within a circle or sphere. Distinct rays of light appear to emanate from behind the lower half of the disc; the sky behind the top half is suffused with light. The upper right portion of the disk is dark. The circle may represent the sun, although the light that radiates around it appears to come from behind the circle itself.
The figure holds dividers or compasses.

The figure and disc are surrounded by clouds on both sides, which separate where the man's arm extends downwards. The dramatic shading on the clouds and the bright light behind the figure suggest either sunrise or sunset or, alternatively, the sky after a storm.
The horizontal position of the figure's hair and beard suggests a strong wind blowing from right to left.

objnote.p: An impression of *Jerusalem* Plate 8 is printed on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. A giant snake is coiled just above the imprint. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. A small crest rises from the top of its head. Its mouth is open; both its long forked tongue and teeth are prominent. Its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" (line 5) in the imprint. The snake's body is patterned with repeating ovals and lines that suggest texture or scales. Below the two large coils of its lower body and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms with leaves; the same vegetation also protrudes from beneath the snake in the bottom left corner of the plate. The dark coloring along the lower edge of the image may suggest earth. The snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

objnote.p: This impression has motifs added by Blake in pencil, pen and ink, and gray wash. The second and third words of the printed title have been partly rubbed off this impression; all but fragments of the serpent's two lower coils have also been deleted. The body of a human figure, bent sharply forward to reveal his(?) back and right foot, has been drawn in pencil and pen and ink over the erased coils. The figure's head merges into the body of the serpent. An impression of *Jerusalem* Plate 70 is printed on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. A nude figure, presumably male, kneels facing out from the plate, arms bent and resting on the ground just above the imprint. His posture suggests a bowed head but instead a giant snake emerges from where his neck meets his shoulders. This snake rises above and to the left of the kneeling figure; its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. A small crest rises from the top of its head. Its mouth is open; both its long, forked tongue and teeth are prominent. The snake's body is patterned with repeating ovals and lines that suggest texture or scales. In other versions of this plate, the serpent's body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" (line 5) in the imprint. In this image, however, the two large coils of the serpent's lower body have been removed and replaced with the nude figure. These loops are still lightly visible behind the nude drawing. Below the left arm of the figure and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms with leaves; the same vegetation also protrudes from beneath the snake in the bottom left corner of the plate. In the lower right corner, the serpentine form with a single loop representing the snake's tail in other copies is visible and here resembles a vine or other vegetation. The dark coloring along the lower edge of the image may suggest earth. In other plates, the snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude figure, presumably male, kneels facing outward from the plate. He is bowed forward at the waist, so that his forearms are resting on the ground. His right foot and part of his upper right thigh are visible; his left leg is completely obscured. His posture suggests a bent neck or lowered head but instead a giant snake emerges from where his neck meets his shoulders. This snake rises above and to the left of the kneeling figure.

Emerging from the bowed neck of the kneeling male figure at right, a giant snake rises along the left side of the plate with its head extended to the right. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. A small crest rises from the top of its head. Its mouth is open; both its long, forked tongue and teeth are prominent. The snake's body is patterned with repeating ovals and lines that suggest texture or scales. In other versions of this plate, its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" (line 5) in the imprint. In this image, however, the two large coils of the serpent's lower body have been scraped away and the nude figure drawn on top of them. These loops are still lightly visible behind the nude drawing. In other plates, the snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

Below the nude figure's left arm and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves. More vegetation protrudes from beneath the snake's body at bottom left. In the lower right corner, the serpentine form with a single loop representing the snake's tail in other copies is visible and here resembles a vine or other vegetation.
The dark coloring along the lower edge of the image may suggest earth.

lg.l: EUROPE
a

PROPHECYAlthough the words "a PROPHECY" are still legible, they appear to have been partially effaced after printing. The letters P, R, O, C, and Y show some indication that they have been decorated with trailing lines of ink, either with brush or pen.
LAMBETH
Printed by Will: Blake: 1794

objnote.p: This impression has motifs added by Blake in pencil, pen and ink, and gray wash. These include three hovering figures below the title word "EUROPE," a bearded male sitting on the head of a serpent and holding a quill (left hand) and two (stone?) tablets, and the head of a figure above the tablets. The printed head of the serpent has been rubbed off this impression and converted into a tail; the serpent's very large head has been drawn below, where two coils of its body appear in the printed image. An impression of *Jerusalem* Plate 74 is printed on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned and bearded old man, presumably Urizen, sits on the massive head of a serpent who faces right. The man’s body is twisted so that his legs are extended to the left along the snake’s head, but his upper body faces forward. The man looks up and to the right; he is holding a quill in his left hand and tablets in his right. His left foot is braced against the body of the snake, which extends upward along the left margin of the image. Its body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral; its tail ends in trailing lines, echoing the form descending from the final E in "EUROPE" (line 2). A crest rises from the top of its head, upon which Urizen is seated. The serpent's mouth is open; it seems to be holding or eating something large in its mouth. Curling lines above suggest waves or clouds. The pattern of ovals and lines on the snake's body suggests scales. The snake may be the serpent-form of Orc. The gray wash underneath the serpent's head, which nearly obscures the imprint, suggests ground or stormy seas. Traces of what may be vines or vegetation emerge to the left and right of the serpent's head, as well as extend from the bottom right of the plate to just below the imprint. This vegetation has been nearly obscured by the gray wash, however. At the top of the image, either emerging from the individual R, O, P, and E of "EUROPE" or from behind those letters, are sketchy shapes that may be the rough forms of angels. The shape trailing from the final E is most clearly figurative, and it may have long hair trailing behind its head. In this image, the original title plate for *Europe: A Prophecy* has been significantly modified. While the coils of the serpent's body to the left of the plate are printed from the copperplate, Blake has switched the serpent's head and tail. Traces of the original printed image are lightly visible to the right of "a" (line 3), underneath the serpent's head, and behind the gray wash at the bottom of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned and bearded old man, presumably Urizen, sits or rides on the massive head of a giant serpent who faces right. The man’s body is twisted so that his legs are extended to the left along the snake’s head, but his upper body faces forward. He looks up and to the right of the panel; his mouth may be open. He is holding a quill in his left hand and tablets in his right. His left arm is bent at a 90 degree angle; his right arm is hidden behind the tablets he is holding. His left foot is braced against the body of the snake and his right foot may be crossed under the left and visible below it.

A serpent carries an old man upon the crest of his giant head. The snake is facing right, and one eye is visible. Its mouth is open, with lower jaw possibly distinguishable behind the gray wash at the bottom of the plate. It appears to be holding or eating a large indeterminate object in its jaws, and curled lines above its nostrils suggest smoke or clouds. The serpent's body rises up and along the left side of the plate in two loops, suggesting a spiral. The serpent's body is patterned with repeated ovals and lines that suggest scales. The lower spiral obscures the bottom left corner of Urizen's tablets. Its forked tail crosses the plate and trails off into two lines at the top right corner of the plate, above Urizen's head. Lightly visible behind the serpent's tail is the head of the serpent from the original printing. This figure may be the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

A group of three figures descend from "Europe" (line 2). Although they are roughly sketched, they appear to be angels. All fly, float, or hover with heads at left and bodies angled diagonally down and left. They appear to wear gowns and may extend one arm forward. The figure furthest right is most clearly figurative, and it may have long hair trailing behind its head.

Below the serpent's lower jaw and right of "Lambeth" (line 5) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves or vines. There are slight indications of more vegetation on the left. The curled line with one loop at the bottom of the plate, which is the serpent's tail in the original print, here takes on the appearance of vegetation as well.
The gray wash below the serpent may be ground or a stormy sea.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with three loops extends from the top of the first letter of the first word ("Europe") in the title. A vine, perhaps with leaves at its end, extends horizontally beneath "Europe" from its third letter. This vine has one loop.

lg.l: EUROPEIn comparison to other copies of this plate, the word PROPHECY has been fully effaced and obscured except for the letters H and E. Parts of the letters E, U, R, and O in EUROPE (line 2) have been similarly scraped away, and the letters R, O, P, and E have been over-drawn with descending figures. The "a" (line 3) is still legible, but has been drawn on; the imprint (lines 5 and 6) is still legible but has been mostly covered by a gray wash.

objnote.p: This impression of the third state (of three) includes only the design above the main text block, color printed and hand colored. Small fragments of the first line of text below the design are visible just above the bottom margin.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This impression includes only the design above the plate. Two figures appear in a landscape. A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles. He faces to the left, toward the other figure. His arms are bent upward at the elbows, with his left forearm and index finger pointing up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left. This figure on the left is a youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest. He strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He looks to the left, perhaps at something out of the frame, and his mouth is slightly open. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler. Below his feet is a path or road that wraps around the bottom of the rocks and cave. Vegetation, perhaps the leaves of trees or a hedge, grows right and left of this walking figure, and above the cave with the assassin. There is additional vegetation with leaves above the cave and at the bottom left of its entrance. Gray sky is visible in the upper left corner and across the top of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His body faces forward but his head turns to the left, looking toward the other figure. His hair is short and curly, and may be tonsured. His arms are bent upward at the elbows, with his left forearm and index finger pointing up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. His mouth is slightly open. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left.

A youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest, strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He steps forward with his right foot, which is prominent. His hair is short and blows behind him in flame-like locks. He looks to the left, perhaps at something out of the frame, and his mouth is slightly open. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler.
The figure with a dagger crouches within a cave formed of large stones.
The walking figure strides forward on a road or path that wraps around the bottom of the rocks and cave.

Vegetation, perhaps the leaves of trees or hedges, surrounds the walking figure and extends above the cave in which the crouching figure sits. There is also undifferentiated vegetation at the base of the cave on the left.
Gray sky is visible in the upper left corner and across the top of the plate.

Clothing may be visible near his hip at right, although he may be nude. His mouth is drawn into an evil smile. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left.

A youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest, strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He steps forward with his right foot, which is prominent. The walking figure strides forward on a road or path that wraps around the bottom of the rocks and cave.

Vegetation, perhaps the leaves of trees or hedges, sits above the cave in which the crouching figure sits. A separate expanse of vegetation fills the area behind the walking figure and presumably reaches behind the cave. There is also undifferentiated vegetation at the base of the cave on both sides. The vegetation to the right of the cave is flame-like in shape and may instead be shadowy grooves in the rock face.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing directly at us, with a pained or despairing expression. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings. At least ten birds fly near the figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing. Further to the right, a nude male falls head-first. His legs are bent at the knees, with the left leg drawn up near his chest. His arms are raised over his head and bent at the elbows with his hands behind his head. A large weight is attached to his hands or arms, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?). This weight apparently pulls him downwards.

component.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing directly at us, with a pained or despairing expression. His eyes are closed or unseeing, and he appears to cry (tears may be visible on both cheeks). Alternatively, the face may be deeply lined with wrinkles indicating advanced age. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings.

A large weight is attached to his arms or hands, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?). This weight apparently pulls him downwards.
A large weight is attached to the arms or hands of the descending figure, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?).
At least ten birds fly near the bat-winged figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There is a good deal of interlinear decoration, particularly in the margins of the text. Most consists of vines and leaves, but there are also a few animals. The first letter of the first word in line 2 ("The") twists into a spiral vine on the left with three loops; it (or another, detached vine) descends with one further loop in the left margin to line 10. A long, wavy vine extends between lines 4 and 5. On it is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 5. Further to the left, under the first word of line 4, is a small form that may be a fly, moth, butterfly, or bee. A vine trails downward from this same first word ("And") in line 4. Just left of the beginning of line 13 is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort. In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word ("And") in the last line of text (line 16). In the right margin, another branch of the vine extending between lines 4 and 5 descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. It bears loops, at least two types of leaves, and perhaps some fruit or flowers. A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of this vine (opposite line 4); a worm or caterpillar inches its way across the upper reaches of a large, slender leaf opposite the space between lines 8 and 9. Other branches of this vine extend above the falling figure and intertwine with the large leaf to the right of this same figure. To the right are two flying birds. A separate vine with spiky leaves twists right of lines 5-7, growing from the "d" in "thunder" (line 8). Below one of its tendrils, and just to the right of line 8, is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly. A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 7; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 8. Far to the right of lines 14-15, between the long leaves and the edge of the plate, are two flying birds.

lg.l: The nameless shadowy female rose from out the breast of Orc:
Her snaky hair brandishing in the winds of Enitharmon;
And thus her voice arose.
O mother Enitharmon wilt thou bring forth other sons?
To cause my name to vanish, that my place may not be found.
For I am faint with travel!
Like the dark cloud disburdend in the day of dismal thunder.
My roots are brandish'd in the heavens. my fruits in earth beneath
Surge, foam, and labour into life, first born & first consum'd!
Consumed and consuming!
Then why shouldst thou accursed mother bring me into life?
I wrap my turban of thick clouds around my lab'ring head:
And fold the sheety waters as a mantle round my limbs,
Yet the red sun and moon,
And all the overflowing stars rain down prolific pains.

objnote.p: This posthumous impression, printed by Frederick Tatham c. 1832, is in the third state (of three).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design showing four nude figures in a dark sky, perhaps at night. The two text panels are shaped like clouds. Upper right, we see a figure from behind with his(?) left leg drawn up and bent at the knee and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended backward; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. Below is a group of three wrestling figures, all nude and bald. The central figure has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right drawn up and bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent (if somewhat abstractly rendered) genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. This central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. The figure on the left has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. The wrestler on the right has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. All three figures have caricature-like facial expressions suggesting fear and pain (figures right and left) or desperation and cruelty (central figure). The dark background surrounding the struggling figures suggests a night scene.

component.illusobjdesc: Upper right, we see a muscular, nude male(?) from behind, facing away, with his left leg drawn up and bent at the knee and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended backward; he may be rising or climbing/striding onto the cloud. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head and short, curly hair. This gesture suggests despair. His muscular back and buttocks are prominent.
A group of three wrestlers, all muscular, nude, and bald males, hovers in the night sky.

The central bald, nude, and muscular male in the group of three wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right drawn up and bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent (if somewhat abstractly rendered) genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. His mouth appears to be slightly open with his facial expression suggesting desperation or cruelty, possibly in an evil smile.

The figure on the left in the group of three nude and bald male wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. His face expresses pain and terror, and his mouth is slightly open, possibly forming a smile.

The wrestler on the right in the group of three nude and bald males has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. He hovers in a supine position. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. His head is bent back as he is being strangled, and his mouth is slightly open; his face expresses pain and terror.

The two text areas are shaped like, and perhaps are supposed to represent, clouds. These clouds extend to the right margin below the figure upper right. Dark clouds appear below the text, where the wrestling figures are backed by a dark sky, which may indicate a storm or perhaps that the time is night.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative and avian motifs decorate the text. A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 2. A similar vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 13. A spiky vine with tendrils or branches hovers above "my voice" in line 16. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine. A faint, single bird flies above "vig'rous" and another, more clear, above "progeny" in line 8, a flock of four birds flies right of line 11, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 13, and a flock of three birds follows line 15.

lg.l: Unwilling I look up to heaven! unwilling count the stars!
Sitting in fathomless abyss of my immortal shrine.
I sieze their burning power
And bring forth howling terrors, all devouring fiery kings.
Devouring & devouréd roaming on dark and desolate mountains
In forests of eternal death, shrieking in hollow trees.
Ah mother Enitharmon!
Stamp not with solid form this vig'rous progeny of fires.
I bring forth from my teeming bosom myriads of flames.
And thou dost stamp them with a signet, then they roam abroad
And leave me void as death;
Ah! I am drown'd in shady woe, and visionary joy.
And who shall bind the infinite with an eternal band?
To compass it with swaddling bands? and who shall cherish it
With milk and honey?
I see it smile & I roll inward & my voice is past.
She ceast & rolld her shady clouds
Into the secret place:

objnote.p: This impression is in the first state (of two). Object 13 (Bentley Plate 4) is printed on the recto.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design showing four nude figures in a dark sky, perhaps at night. The two text panels are shaped like clouds. Upper right, we see a figure from behind with his(?) left leg drawn up and bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended backward; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. Below is a group of three wrestling figures, all nude and bald. The central figure has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right drawn up and bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent (if somewhat abstractly rendered) genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. This central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. The figure on the left has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. The wrestler on the right has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. All three figures have caricature-like facial expressions suggesting fear and pain (figures right and left) or desperation and cruelty (central figure). The dark background surrounding the four struggling figures suggests a night scene.

component.illusobjdesc: Upper right, we see a muscular nude male(?) from behind, facing away, with his left leg drawn up and bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended backward; he may be rising or climbing/striding onto the cloud. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head and short, curly hair. This gesture suggests despair. His muscular back and buttocks are prominent.
A group of three wrestlers, all muscular, nude, and bald males, hovers in the night sky.

The central bald, nude, and muscular male in the group of three wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right drawn up and bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent (if somewhat abstractly rendered) genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. His mouth appears to be slightly open with his facial expression suggesting desperation or cruelty, possibly in an evil smile.

The figure on the left in the group of three nude and bald male wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. His face expresses pain and terror, and his mouth is slightly open, possibly forming a smile.

The wrestler on the right in the group of three nude and bald males has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. He hovers in a supine position. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. His head is bent back as he is being strangled, and his mouth is slightly open; his face expresses pain and terror.

The two text areas are shaped like, and perhaps are supposed to represent, clouds. These clouds extend to the right margin below the figure upper right. The wrestling figures are backed by a dark sky, which may indicate that the time is night.
