objnote.p: This impression of Bentley Plate 6 includes only a middle portion of the plate, extending from the lower part of the large hovering winged figure (wings trimmed off) to just below line 15 of the text (ending "...distant north"). Object 21 (Bentley Plate 7) is printed on the verso. Objects 18 and 21, printed recto/verso, may have been cut from the same impressions of Bentley Plates 6 and 7 from which Objects 19 and 20 were also cut, although the ink colors of Object 20 and 21 now appear to be somewhat different.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This impression has been cropped from one that contains a good deal of text and a great deal of interlinear decoration, in addition to major pictorial motifs that constitute a full-plate design. The text panels are shaped like, and may represent, clouds floating in the sky. The largest figure, hovering horizontally in the air is a gowned female. Her body is twisted, facing forward at her hips and facing down above the waist. Her long, curled hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and she holds the back of her head with her hands. In the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space. Below her cascading hair is a nude male(?) in a contracted posture. He seems confined by the circle in which he sits. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. It may be a planet. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. He faces forward. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 2), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (plates 15-17, line 8). The other motifs on this plate, including many human figures, will be treated as interlinear designs.

component.illusobjdesc: The largest figure on the plate, hovering horizontally in the air, is a gowned female. Her body is twisted, facing forward at her hips and facing down above the waist around which she wears a belt. Her long, curled hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are behind her head. In the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space.

A nude male(?) in a very contracted posture sits within a circle. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 2), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (plates 15-17, line 8).

A figure squats or sits within a circle which may be meant to represent a globe. It has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. Hence, this may be a planet. Flames surround the figure within the globe.
The two text panels and the extension of the uppermost cloud on which the largest figure lies are shaped like, and may be intended to represent, clouds against the sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The cloud-like text panel containing lines 1-5 of the text includes three human figures, birds, and some vines. A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 1 and turns to the right over the line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops. To the right of the second loop sits a gowned (or at least wearing a skirt) and apparently female figure. Her body faces to the left. Her left arm extends downward to her knee, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees and extended to the right. Above her and to the left is a flock of five birds. Two figures hover in the air right of line 1. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. To the right is a figure also hovering and seen from behind. His(?) left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it. To the right of this figure, and above "eternal" in line 3, is a vine. Another vine, with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 5. To the right of this line are two birds, flying upward on extended wings.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably female and wearing a gown (or at least a skirt), sits on the vine above "deep of" in line 1 of the text. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees, and she may be pointing.

Two figures hover in the air right of line 1 of the text. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. She appears to turn her head to the right, perhaps to look at the figure beside her. The hem of her gown forms a twisting tail.

To the right of line 1, and right of the hovering female figure, is a figure also hovering and seen from behind. His(?) left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee and drawn up. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it.
The figure hovering above "eternal" (line 3) holds, and presumably plays, a horn with one loop in it.
A flock of five birds flies on extended wings above the vine extending horizontally above line 1 of the text.
Two birds fly upwards on extended wings right of line 5 of the text.
A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 1 of the text and turns to the right over this line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops.
A vine curls above "eternal" in line 3 of the text.
A vine, perhaps with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 5 of the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four figures, birds, a cloud outline, and a vine decorate the second cloud-like text panel containing lines 6-13 of the text. A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 6 and extends above the line to the word "her." A much smaller vine or single leaf grows from the vertical of the last letter in this line. Just above the first word ("Then"), a nude figure (probably male) lies supine on this vine. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body. The figure above may be gowned (note the suggestion of trailing drapery) and of uncertain gender. This figure's legs are spread and one arm (the left?) is raised vertically. The figure may be rising in the air. To the right, above "Enitharmon" in line 6, is a flying bird. Another two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 10. A cloud outline (or perhaps the surface of the earth?) below and to the right of the birds bears a figure crawling to the right on all fours. Further to the right, another figure, perhaps nude and female, stands and leans to the left against the cloud outline. Her legs are crossed.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude figure, probably male, lies supine on the vine above the first word ("Then") in line 6 of the text. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body.

A figure, facing left, hovers above the first letter of "Enitharmon" in line 6 of the text. This figure, of uncertain gender, has his or her (left?) arm raised vertically and legs spread. The figure may be gowned (note the slight suggestion of a tail of drapery) and rising.
A figure crawls to the right on all fours along the cloud outline (or surface of the earth?) above the last word ("rest") in line 11 of the text. The figure may be gowned.
A figure, probably nude and female, stands and leans to the left against a cloud outline. Her upper body, twisted to the left, is braced against the cloud with her left arm; her legs are crossed.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above the middle letters of "Enitharmon" (and above the vine), line 6 of the text.
Two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 10 of the text.
A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 6 and extends above the line to the word "her."
The vertical of the final letter of "around," the last word in line 6 of the text, becomes a vine arching over the word. It may terminate in a leaf.

A cloud outline extends from the right margin of the plate and ends above the last word ("come") in line 10 of the text. Perhaps the segment of this line on the left, where a figure is crawling, is meant to represent the surface of the earth rather than a cloud.

lg.l: The deep of winter came;
What time the secret child,
Descended thro' the orient gates of the eternal day;
War ceas'd, & all the troops like shadows fled
to their abodes.
Then Enitharmon saw her sons & daughters rise around,
Like pearly clouds they meet together in the crystal house:
And Los. possessor of the moon, joy'd in the peaceful night;
Thus speaking while his num'rous sons shook their bright fiery wings
Again the night is come
That strong Urthona takes his rest,
And Urizen unloos'd from chains
Glows like a meteor in the distant north

objnote.p: This impression of Bentley Plate 6 includes only the top portion of the plate, extending from the top edge to the upper half of the body of the large hovering winged angel. The hand coloring is very probably not by Blake. Object 20 (Bentley Plate 7) is printed on the verso. Objects 18 and 21, printed recto/verso, may have been cut from the same impressions of Bentley Plates 6 and 7 from which Objects 19 and 20 were also cut, although the ink colors of Objects 20 and 21 now appear to be somewhat different.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This impression shows only a top portion of the full plate design. The header text and a portion of one major pictorial motif are present. The largest figure, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail at left. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist, although much of her upper body is not depicted as it is below the lower margin of the design. However, her hands protrude from the bottom edge of the plate and are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (plates 13 and 14 line 2) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (plates 13 and 14 line 13). The pink coloring of the sky and clouds may suggest sunrise or sunset. The other motifs on this plate, including many human figures, will be treated as interlinear designs.

component.illusobjdesc: The header text and large hovering figure are surrounded by forms shaped like, and that may be intended to represent, clouds against a sky. The pink coloring may suggest sunrise or sunset.

The largest figure on the plate, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist around which she wears a belt. Much of her upper body is not depicted as it is below the lower margin of the design. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail at left. Her hands protrude from the bottom edge of the plate and are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (plates 13 and 14 line 2) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (plates 13 and 14 line 13).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The heading is surrounded by several figures and vegetative motifs. The figures, particularly the larger ones, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 8) of Enitharmon referred to on complete copies of the plate. The lower left corner of "A" (in "A / PROPHECY" [lines 1-2]) grows into a long vine with branches. Standing on this vine, near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female. On the right foot of "A" is a tree, possibly a palm, with branches that bend downward. To the left of the "A" and slightly below it is a male(?) embracing a female. Both hover in the air, with the male on the right and facing to the left. Both have long hair and the male appears nude, while the woman has a long, snake-like tail of drapery extending from her lower torso. The man's body is twisted into a left-facing curve, seen from behind. His left arm is raised horizontally and embraces the woman's waist. His right leg is extended horizontally. We also see the woman from behind, with her body twisted into a curve matching the man's. Both her arms are raised horizontally, with her head facing down. These gestures suggest that she is trying to escape from the man. In contrast, the couple right of the letter "A" is embracing mutually and appear to be kissing. The winged male(?), possibly an angel, hovers horizontally in the air, with his arms raised at 45 degrees to embrace the woman(?) who hovers vertically. She too is winged and may be an angel. Her legs are bent back and her arms raised at 135 degrees to embrace her companion. He faces down and to the left; she faces up and to the right. Below the "A" is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline. Other cloud outlines extend to the upper right and below "PROPHECY" in the heading. On the right, below a cloud outline and above the last letter of "PROPHECY," two nude figures seen from behind soar in the sky, left arms raised horizontally and right arms raised at 135 degrees. The letters of "PROPHECY" are well decorated with eight human figures and vines. Proceeding from left to right, these include a vine with leaves or lily-like flowers intertwined with the first letter and extending to the second. A small standing figure holds the vertical of the first "P" and may be climbing. Another figure stands on the foot of the vertical of the "R" and faces to the left with arms raised vertically. Above this figure is a small form that may be a descending child or infant, arms stretched downward toward the adult. The right foot of the "R" bears a very small seated figure, hunched over and facing to the right. The letter "O" has two vines with lily-like flowers. Standing within the "O" is a figure facing forward and with left arm raised horizontally to hold a shepherd's crook. To the right of this shepherd is a small flock of sheep. Three vines, or perhaps flames, spring from the foot of the second "P." A vine, perhaps with a few leaves, is intertwined with the next three letters ("HEC"). The final vine in this group springs from the foot of the final letter and forms a spiral above and to the right of the letter. This "Y" also bears three human figures. One, seen from behind and with legs spread and arms raised vertically, seems to be climbing, with the right foot on the foot of the "Y" and the left foot on the "C." Above, standing on the top left end of the "Y," is a figure facing left who may walk to the left with one leg extended backward. Finally, the first bend in the vine growing from the right side of the final letter bears a seated figure facing right, with back slightly hunched over and right arm extended to the right knee. This figure holds a book or tablet and is probably reading. Two flames, or perhaps a flame-like plant, spring from the foot of the "Y" on its right side.

component.illusobjdesc: The human figures surrounding the heading, particularly the four largest figures, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 8) of Enitharmon referred to on complete copies of the plate.

Standing on the vine springing from the lower left of the letter "A" (line 1), near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female.

Below and left of the "A" in the title (line 2), a nude male(?), hovering in the air, embraces a female with his left arm around her waist. We see him from behind, but his body is twisted into a curve. His hair is long; his right leg is extended horizontally to the left. He faces left. This vignette may also allude to the myth of Daphne, illustrating the pursuit that prefigured her metamorphosis.

Below and left of the "A" in the title (line 1), a partly nude female with long hair, facing down and to the left, hovers in the air. She is embraced around the waist by the male(?) to the right. We see her from behind, with her body twisted into a curve like the male's. Her long hair, perhaps in a braid, extends behind her to the right. Although apparently nude from the waist up, a long, snake-like tail of drapery extends from her lower torso. Her arms are raised horizontally to the right. This gesture, as well as her head position, suggest that she is trying to flee from the male. This vignette may also allude to the myth of Daphne, illustrating the pursuit that prefigured her metamorphosis.

Right of the "A" in the title (line 1), a nude male(?) hovers horizontally and reaches down, with his arms at 45 degrees, to embrace the female(?) below and to the left. His large wings suggest he may be an angel. He faces down and to the left and may be kissing the female. His hair may be curly.

Right of the "A" in the title (line 1), a nude female(?) hovers in the air. Her large wings suggest she may be an angel. She reaches up with her arms raised at 135 degrees to embrace the male(?) hovering horizontally to the right. Her legs are extended behind her and slightly bent at the knee. She faces up and to the right and may be kissing the male.

Below the "A" (line 1) of the heading is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline.

A small figure holds the vertical of the first letter of "PROPHECY" (line 2) in the heading. The figure reaches up with both arms and may be climbing. The figure probably faces forward or to the right. Its right leg appears to be dangling or extended downwards while the left leg may be wrapped around the letter.

A small figure stands, facing left, on the foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 2). The figure, probably male, has his arms raised vertically, perhaps to catch the small figure above. His right leg is extended backward.

Just above the figure standing on the left foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 2) is a very small human form, probably a child or infant. This tiny figure descends or falls head-first toward the adult below, with arms reaching downward.
A very small figure sits on the right foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 2). The figure faces right and is slightly hunched over.

A figure, probably male, stands within the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). He faces forward with his left arm raised horizontally. He holds a shepherd's crook in his left hand. Given the crook and the flock of sheep to the right, the figure is almost certainly a shepherd.

A figure, probably male and seen from behind, climbs between the "C" and "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). His legs are spread, with his left foot poised on the "C" and his right foot just touching the foot of the "Y." He reaches up vertically with both arms to hold the left diagonal of the "Y." He may wear tights.

A figure, probably male, stands, or perhaps walks, on top of the left diagonal of the "Y" in "PROPHECY" (line 2). He is probably facing to the left and one leg appears to be extended behind him. He may hold an indistinguishable object in his left hand by his side.

A small figure, probably gowned and male, sits on the vine extending from the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). He faces to the right, with his upper body hunched over and his right arm extended at 45 degrees to his knees. He holds, and seems to be reading, a book or tablet.
The figure sitting on the vine extending from the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2) appears to be holding a book or tablet.

Two figures hover in, or fly through, the air above the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). Both are probably males, nude and seen from behind. Both have their left arms raised horizontally, their right arms raised at 135 degrees, and their legs extended backward behind them.
A flock of sheep rests within the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 2), just to the right of their shepherd.
Flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the second "P" of "PROPHECY" (line 2) on its right side.
Two flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2) on its right side.

The outlines of clouds extend above "PROPHECY" (line 2) from the "O" to the upper right corner of the plate; one cloud outline descends between the second "P" and "H" of the word and extends below the word to the "R."
A vine, perhaps with leaves, extends to the left from the left foot of "A" (line 1) in the heading.
The raised arms of the figure standing on the left foot of "A" (line 1) in the heading vegetate into branches that arch downward. This may be a willow.
A small tree with arching branches, perhaps a palm, grows from the right foot of "A" (line 1) in the heading.

A vine is intertwined with the first letter of "PROPHECY" (line 2) in the heading. There are leaves or perhaps lily-like flowers at its left end; its right end curls behind the foot of the next letter ("R").

A vine with lily-like flowers is intertwined with the left side of the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). A separate vine, or the other end of the same vine, grows up the right side of the same letter. It too bears lily-like flowers.
A vine with one loop and a few leaves is intertwined with the letters "HEC" of "PROPHECY" (line 2).
A vine, with a spiral upper right, grows from the right side of the foot of "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2).

objnote.p: This impression of Plate 7 includes only 15 lines of text and accompanying marginal designs. Lines 1 and 2 of the full plate text have been trimmed off at the top; all except the tops of the letters in line 18 of the complete text have been trimmed off at the bottom. The hand coloring is probably not by Blake. Object 19 (Bentley Plate 6) is printed on the recto. Objects 18 and 21, Bentley Plates 6 and 7 printed recto/verso, may have been cut from the same impressions of Plates 6 and 7 from which Objects 19 and 20 were also cut, although the ink colors of Objects 20 and 21 now appear to be somewhat different.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This impression shows only an upper portion of the plate. The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is well decorated with vines, one fairly large human figure, and animals. Right of lines 5-8 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down, and his arms raised and wrapped around his head. His head is uncolored in this copy, and he may be bald. Right of line 2 are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird(?), a winged insect (perhaps a beetle, dragonfly, or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird. Another winged creature, perhaps an insect, flies right of lines 5-6. Left and right of this creature are two vines; the vine on the right looks very worm-like. A vine below line 7 includes one loop and a grain tassel on its right end. A grasshopper or locust stands on this vine, facing right. Three winged insects fly above the grain tassel. Another vine appears further to the right, with at least one leaf and three loops. Vines, or extensions of a cloud outline, extend below line 12. A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 15 and a vine grows from the "h" of the next word ("Enitharmon").

component.illusobjdesc: Right of lines 5-8 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down, and his arms bent upward and wrapped around his head. His head is uncolored in this copy, and he may be bald.
Right of line 2 of the text are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird(?), a winged insect (perhaps a beetle, dragonfly, or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird.
A winged creature, perhaps an insect such as a moth, dragonfly, or beetle, flies right of lines 5-6 of the text.
A grasshopper or locust sits, facing right, on the vine above line 8 of the text.
Three flying insects, perhaps flies or moths, appear below "nights of" in line 7 of the text. The first from the left may be a dragonfly.
A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 15 of the text.
Two vines appear right of lines 5-6 of the text. The vine on the right is very worm-like.
Two vines appear right of lines 5-6 of the text. The vine on the right is very worm-like.
A vine with one loop and a grain tassel at its right end appears between lines 7 and 8 of the text.
A vine with three loops and one leaf winds its way between lines 7 and 8 of the text, left of the descending figure.
An extension of a cloud outline between lines 12 and 13 of the text takes on the appearance of a vine.
A vine grows from the "h" of "Enitharmon," the second word in line 15 of the text.

lg.l: Sieze all the spirits of life and bindThe upper portions of several words in line 1 are cut off by the upper margin of this trimmed impression.
Their warbling joys to our loud strings
Bind all the nourishing sweets of earth
To give us bliss, that we may drink the sparkling wine of Los
And let us laugh at war,
Despising toil and care.
Because the days and nights of joy. in lucky hours renew.
Arise O Orc from thy deep den,
First born of Enitharmon rise!
And we will crown thy head with garlands of the ruddy vine;
For now thou art bound;
And I may see thee in the hour of bliss, my eldest born,
The horrent Demon rose, surrounded with red stars of fire,
Whirling about in furious circles round the immortal fiend.

Then Enitharmon down descended into his red light, Below line 15, the upper portions of several letters, line 18 of the full plate text, are visible protruding from the lower edge of the design. The text, however, is not legible here.

objnote.p: This impression (second state of two) has been trimmed to the design below the text. Object 18 (Bentley Plate 6) is printed on the recto. Objects 18 and 21, printed recto/verso, may have been cut from the same impressions of Bentley Plates 6 and 7 from which Objects 19 and 20 were also cut, although the ink colors of Objects 20 and 21 now appear to be somewhat different.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This impression shows only the design below the text. The design consists of two large figures and five smaller ones; in other copies, text appears in clouds above the figures. A nude and youthful male lies prone on the ground—or perhaps on a bed of straw. He faces down, with his arms bent upward and his head resting on them. Only part of his left arm and right hand are visible. His hair is curly, and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc. Above him, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended and her right bent at the knee under her torso. Her arms are extended vertically above her head and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. She is probably Enitharmon. The five much smaller figures above may be her sons and daughters. In the left corner of the design, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left, head apparently down. The gender of this figure is uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion. Similar exhaustion is indicated by the nude figure to the right. This figure is probably female and also lies supine on a cloud. Her body is bent back, with her head, right arm, and right leg dangling downward. Above and to the right is another nude female, sitting or reclining supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and probably has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee. Further to the right is an embracing couple hovering in the air, with the woman on the right. They may be kissing. The nude male, facing right, has his legs spread and his right arm raised horizontally. The female, facing left, is gowned—or at least has a tail of drapery curling over her raised left leg. Her legs are spread apart. Her long hair may be gathered into a bun.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude and youthful male lies prone on the ground—or perhaps on a bed of straw. He faces down, with his arms bent upward and his head resting on them at left. Only part of his left arm and right hand are visible. His hair is short and curly, and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc.

Above the youthful male lying prone, a nude female with long, curly, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended, her right bent at the knee and drawn up under her torso. Her arms are extended vertically above her head and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. Her mouth is slightly open. She is probably Enitharmon.
A nude female leans over the male lying prone, and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking.
Five nude figures fill the sky. These may be the sons and daughters of Enitharmon.

In the left corner of the design, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left, head apparently down. This figure may grasp its head with its right hand. The gender of this figure is uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion.
A nude figure, probably female, lies supine on a cloud, head at left. Her posture suggests erotic exhaustion, with her head bent back and her right arm and right leg dangling downward.

A nude female sits or lies supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and probably has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee.

A nude male with short hair, facing right, embraces a female and perhaps kisses her. He hovers in the air, with legs spread and slightly bent, and right leg extended backward. His right arm is raised horizontally.

A partly nude female, facing left, hovers in the air and apparently embraces—and perhaps kisses—the male to the left. Her legs are spread apart with her left leg bent and extended backward to touch the cloud above. A gown or piece of drapery curves over her left leg, forming a curling tail. Her long hair may be twisted into a bun.
The youthful and nude male lies on the ground—or perhaps a bed of straw.
The large female figure, and the three smaller figures above her on the left, lie or kneel on clouds.

objnote.p: This impression is in the first state (of three). An impression of *Europe* Plate 17 in the first state (of three) is printed on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is an enclosed interior space with a visible floor and back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate. Above is a large cooking pot with a handle suspended from the top of the fireplace by a short rod. Clouds of smoke or steam billow above the pot. In the foreground are three figures. On the left is a gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture. She sits or squats on the floor with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head is down between her knees; her long hair cascades to the ground beside her prominent right foot. The gowned woman on the right sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair (though the style of the chair is clearer in other copies). Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her left hand is visible near her right breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with a worried or pained expression, perhaps looking at the pot. Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a white cloth spread on the floor. His eyes may be open but he is probably dead. His hair is curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture, sits or squats on the floor with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head is down between her knees; her long hair cascades to the ground. Her right foot is prominent.

At right, a gowned woman sits in a chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed at the ankle. Her left foot is prominent and may touch the body of the child in front of her. She holds her left hand near her right breast. She wears a necklace of pearls or beads and faces up with her neck twisted to the left and with a pained or worried expression on her face. She may be looking at the pot.

Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a white cloth spread on the floor. His head is at left and his right arm lays by his side. His eyes may be open but he is probably dead. His hair is short and curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse.

The setting is an enclosed interior space with a visible floor and back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate.
A large cooking pot hangs in the fireplace from a short rod. Smoke or steam billows above the pot.
The apparently dead child lies on a cloth or blanket spread on the floor.
The gowned woman on the right sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair (though the style of the chair is clearer in other copies).

objnote.p: This posthumous impression, printed by Frederick Tatham c. 1832, is in the third state (of three).

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state (of two). An impression of *Europe* Plate 5 is on the recto of this impression.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The background of the design is composed of a brick wall with a large wooden door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US" with a cross below the inscription. Left of the door is a standing, and perhaps walking, figure wearing a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at his side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This bellman can be associated with the theme of plague dominating the design (particularly when coupled with the inscription on the door, which was typical of quarantined houses). Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out, "Bring out your dead!" Below the bellman on the left are a man and woman. The man, wearing a gown or at least a shirt, appears against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman with his right arm. His hair is curly. The gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man. Her hair is long and her arms are at her side. Her face, with mouth open like her companion’s, expresses despair and perhaps pain, and the limp posture of her body indicates that she may be weak with plague. To the right, a gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; like her companions, she has an expression of pain or despair possibly indicative of the plague.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of four figures—a bellman and three figures with expressions of pain or despair—indicates that this is a picture of the plague. This is confirmed by the inscription on the door in the background, typical of what was written on the doors of quarantined houses during the great plague of London in 1665.

A standing, and perhaps walking, figure wears a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at his side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This is a bellman, tolling the time. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out during the plague, "Bring out your dead!"

A male wearing a gown or shirt sits against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman to the right with his right arm. His hair is curly and his mouth is open. His facial expression indicates pain (from disease?) and despair.

A gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man to the left. Her hair is long and her arms are at her side. Both feet are visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her face, with mouth open like her companion's, expresses despair and perhaps pain. Her limp posture may indicate disease or death.

A gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back and mouth open; her left foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown. Like her companions, she has an expression of pain or despair indicative of disease.
The background of the design is composed of a brick wall with a large wooden door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US" with a cross below the inscription.

lg.l: LORD
AVE MERC
ON US

objnote.p: This impression (in the second state of two) is printed in at least three ink colors, black, reddish brown, and yellow ochre. The greenish-blue coloring may be color printing in an opaque water-based pigment rather than ink.

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state of two. Object 38 (Bentley Plate 17) is printed on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text panel, shaped like a cloud, are two figures in a very dark, perhaps stormy, environment. A gowned and elderly male with long hair and beard stands on the right facing to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with palms outward (that is, facing to the left). His worried expression, staring eyes, and arm gesture suggest that he is afraid of some unpictured presence to the left. He may be Albion's Angel, frightened at the prospect of coming revolution. A gowned woman kneels on the ground before the old man, with right leg extended backward and left leg bent at the knee. Her body is bent forward and her head down. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she embraces the old man around his legs; her right hand seems to press upon the old man’s buttocks. Her long, curly hair cascades below her right upper arm. She may be supplicating the man for help. Forms in the background suggests dark clouds or smoke, illuminated from the left. Perhaps the unpictured presence to the left is the fires of revolution. The darkness left and right suggests a night scene.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned and elderly male with long hair and beard stands on the right facing to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with palms outward (that is, facing to the left). Both feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown. His worried expression, staring eyes, and arm gesture suggest that he is afraid of some unpictured presence to the left. He may be Albion's Angel, frightened by the coming revolution.

A gowned woman kneels on the ground before the old man, with right leg extended backward and right foot visible. Her left leg is bent at the knee. Her body is bent forward and her head down. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she embraces the old man around the legs; her right hand seems to press upon the old man’s buttocks. Her long, curly hair cascades below her right upper arm. She may be supplicating the man for help.

lg.l: Arise O Rintrah eldest born: second to none but Orc:
O lion Rintrah raise thy fury from thy forests black;
Bring Palamabron horned priest, skipping upon the mountains;
And silent Elynittria the silver bowed queen:
Rintrah where hast thou hid thy bride!
Weeps she in desart shades?
Alas my Rintrah! bring the lovely jealous Ocalythron,
Arise my son! bring all thy brethren O thou king of fire.
Prince of the sun I see thee with thy innumerable race;
Thick as the summer stars:
But each ramping his golden mane shakes.
And thine eyes rejoice because of strength O Rintrah furious king.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Grain stems grow from the lower left corner of the plate and coil upward into the large design above the text. Several vines, at least one of which bears ivy-like leaves, are intertwined with the lower reaches of the stems, below and right of the text. The stems form a large "C" curve above the text and end near the right margin in grain tassels. Two figures appear within this "C" curve. The nude female, on the left, is seen from behind; her long hair is formed into a loose bun. She hovers in the air, with her right leg extended and her left bent at the knee. Her body and head are twisted to the right. She holds in her raised right hand, and no doubt plays, a large, coiled horn or trumpet. The trumpet she is playing emits a spray of dark blotches or blight that intermingles with the grain. Her male companion plays a similar horn, to similar effect. He is also nude, seen from behind, and has his body twisted dramatically to the right. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee as he hovers in the air. He holds his coiled horn or trumpet with his left hand. Both arms are raised horizontally, with the right arm extending horizontally into the grain. His hair is short and curly.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female is seen from behind; her long hair is formed into a loose bun with one strand of hair forming a vine-like tail left of the bun. She hovers in the air, with her right leg extended and her left bent at the knee. On her left foot, there is a noticeable gap between her big toe and the other four toes. Her body and head are twisted to the right and her face is tilted upwards. She holds in her raised right hand, and no doubt plays, a large, coiled horn or trumpet. The black spots of blight covering the grain appear to emanate from the trumpet and the one her male companion plays.

The black spots of blight covering the grain appear to emanate from the trumpet and the one his female companion plays.

Another offshoot of the vine in the right margin extends between lines 8 and 12. Three other vines that all may have leaves appear further to the left between lines 5 and 6. The rightmost of these vines is detached, the middle grows from the first letter of "years" in line 5, and the leftmost extends upward from "Shadows" in line 6. A vine-like extension also grows from “by” in line 16. Two vines or leaves, and more spots of blight, appear right of line 13. Three birds or insects may fly to the right of line 11.

lg.l: Enitharmon slept,
Eighteen hundred years; Man was a Dream!
The night of Nature and their harps unstrung:
She slept in middle of her nightly song.
Eighteen hundred years, a female dream!
Shadows of men in fleeting bands upon the winds:
Divide the heavens of Europe;
Till Albions Angel smitten with his own plagues fled with his bands
The cloud bears hard on Albions shore;
Fill'd with immortal demons of futurity:
In council gather the smitten Angels of Albion
The cloud bears hard upon the council house; down rushing
On the heads of Albions Angels.
One hour they lay buried beneath the ruins of that hall;
But as the stars rise from the salt lake they arise in pain,
In troubled mists o'erclouded by the terrors of strugling times,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A snake extends below the text, up the left margin, and above the text. Its tail is in the lower margin; its body, in the left margin, has seven loops or coils suggesting, if not quite forming, a spiral; its head rises above the text. Its mouth is open and its upper teeth are visible; its forked tongue merges with the halo of flames surrounding its crested head. The patterning of the snake's body suggests scales. This is probably the serpent-form of Orc, the spirit of revolution, although a more immediate textual context on this plate appears in line 17: "Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent."

lg.l: (following
In thoughts perturb'd they rose from the bright ruins silent
The fiery King, who sought his ancient temple serpent-form'd
That stretches out its shady length along the Island white.
Round him roll'd his clouds of war; silent the Angel went,
Along the infinite shores of Thames to golden Verulam.
There stand the venerable porches that high-towering rear
Their oak-surrounded pillars, form'd of massy stones, uncut
With tool; stones precious; such eternal in the heavens,
Of colours twelve. few known on earth, give light in the opake.
Plac'd in the order of the stars, when the five senses whelm'd
In deluge o'er the earth-born man; then turn'd the fluxile eyes
Into two stationary orbs, concentrating all things.
The ever-varying spiral ascents to the heavens of heavens
Were bended downward; and the nostrils golden gates shut
Turn'd outward, barr'd and petrify'd against the infinite.
Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent; that which pitieth:
To a devouring flame; and man fled from its face and hid
In forests of night; then all the eternal forests were divided
Into earths rolling in circles of space, that like an ocean
rush'd
And overwhelmed all except this finite wall of flesh.
Then was the serpent temple form'd, image of infinite
Shut up in finite revolutions, and man became an Angel;
Heaven a mighty circle turning; God a tyrant crown'd.
Now arriv'd the ancient Guardian at the southern porch,
That planted thick with trees of blackest leaf, & in a vale
Obscure, inclos'd the Stone of Night; oblique it stood, o'erhung
With purple flowers and berries red; image of that sweet south,
Once open to the heavens and elevated on the human neck,
Now overgrown with hair and coverd with a stony roof, (feet
Downward 'tis sunk beneath th' attractive north, that round the
A raging whirlpool draws the dizzy enquirer to his grave.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A snake extends below the text, up the left margin, and above the text. Its tail is in the lower margin; its body, in the left margin, has seven loops or coils suggesting, if not quite forming, a spiral; its head rises above the text. Its mouth is open and its upper teeth are visible; its forked tongue merges with the halo of flames surrounding its crested head. The patterning of the snake's body suggests scales. This is probably the serpent-form of Orc, the spirit of revolution, although a more immediate textual context on this plate appears in line 17: "Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent."

lg.l: (following
In thoughts perturb'd they rose from the bright ruins silent
The fiery King, who sought his ancient temple serpent-form'd
That stretches out its shady length along the Island white.
Round him roll'd his clouds of war; silent the Angel went,
Along the infinite shores of Thames to golden Verulam.
There stand the venerable porches that high-towering rear
Their oak-surrounded pillars, form'd of massy stones, uncut
With tool; stones precious; such eternal in the heavens,
Of colours twelve. few known on earth, give light in the opake.
Plac'd in the order of the stars, when the five senses whelm'd
In deluge o'er the earth-born man; then turn'd the fluxile eyes
Into two stationary orbs, concentrating all things.
The ever-varying spiral ascents to the heavens of heavens
Were bended downward; and the nostrils golden gates shut
Turn'd outward, barr'd and petrify'd against the infinite.
Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent; that which pitieth:
To a devouring flame; and man fled from its face and hid
In forests of night; then all the eternal forests were divided
Into earths rolling in circles of space, that like an ocean
rush'd
And overwhelmed all except this finite wall of flesh.
Then was the serpent temple form'd, image of infinite
Shut up in finite revolutions, and man became an Angel;
Heaven a mighty circle turning; God a tyrant crown'd.
Now arriv'd the ancient Guardian at the southern porch,
That planted thick with trees of blackest leaf, & in a vale
Obscure, inclos'd the Stone of Night; oblique it stood, o'erhung
With purple flowers and berries red; image of that sweet south,
Once open to the heavens and elevated on the human neck,
Now overgrown with hair and coverd with a stony roof, (feet
Downward 'tis sunk beneath th' attractive north, that round the
A raging whirlpool draws the dizzy enquirer to his grave.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned male sits on a throne-like chair, the chair in turn resting on a cloud. He faces forward and wears the triple-crown of a Pope. His face, however, may be a caricature of George III. He holds on his lap an open book. Large, bat-like wings extend from behind his arms. In some copies, the figure appears to have bat-like ears that merge with the pointed arches on the throne behind him. However, in this copy the figure has human ears. The back of his chair resembles the facade of a Gothic church, with arches and spires right and left. Below this Pope, and below the cloud, are two female angels, right and left, with large wings. Both have long hair, are gowned, bow and look down, and have one arm extended at 45 degrees. Each holds in her extended hand a scepter or staff with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower termination. These two angels have small snake-like tails (or perhaps simply vines) projecting from the hems of their gowns. The darkness behind the three figures may suggest it is night.

The chair in which the male sits is placed on a cloud, and another cloud forms the textual area of the design. The darkness behind the three figures may suggest it is night.

He saw Urizen on the Atlantic;
And his brazen Book,
That Kings & Priests had copied on Earth
Expanded from North to South.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is a stone prison cell with stone stairs rising on the right. A prisoner, lower left, has shackles on both ankles; the shackles are in turn attached to the stone floor with two heavy chains. The prisoner is a nude male with curly hair who sits on a stone ledge. His prominent knees are drawn up to his chest and his legs crossed at the ankles. His body faces forward but his neck is twisted to the right; his head is back and he seems to look up at the figure on the right. His arms are bent at the elbows with his hands raised, palms facing the viewer and fingers spread apart. His gestures and open eye indicate fear and perhaps pain; he may be crying. We see the male figure on the right from behind as he ascends the stairs (right leg extended backwards, left leg bent forward). Except for what may be a belt around his waist, he is nude. His hair is curly. His right arm is at his side. He appears to be holding something in his right hand, but the print is too dark to identify the object; in other prints it is clear that these are keys. He may be the other man's jailor.

component.illusobjdesc: A prisoner, lower left, has shackles on both ankles; the shackles are in turn attached to the stone floor with two heavy chains. The prisoner is a nude male with curly hair who sits on a stone ledge. His prominent knees are drawn up to his chest and his legs crossed at the ankles. His body faces forward but his neck is twisted to the right; his head is back and he seems to look up at the figure on the right. His arms are bent at the elbows with his hands raised, palms facing the viewer and fingers spread apart. His gestures and open eye indicate fear and perhaps pain; he may be crying.
A prisoner, lower left, has shackles on both ankles; the shackles are in turn attached to the stone floor with two heavy chains.

We see from behind a male figure ascending the stairs (right leg extended backwards, left leg bent forward). Except for what may be a belt or apron around his waist, he is nude. His hair is curly. His right arm is at his side and he may be holding an object in his right hand. He may be the other man's jailor. The mottled texture of his skin hints at a disease or perhaps scales or hair.
The setting for the two figures is a prison cell with stairs on the right. The walls, stairs, and floor appear to be built of stones.
A dark diagonal shadow covers the lower right corner of the scene. There are other shadows on the floor to the left of the seated man and on the wall to the right of the jailor.

lg.l: The red limb'd Angel siez'd - in horror and torment;
The Trump of the last doom; but he could not blow the iron tube!
Thrice he assay'd presumptuous to awake the dead to Judgment.
A mighty Spirit leap'd from the land of Albion,
Nam'd Newton; he siez'd the Trump, & blow'd the enormous blast!
Yellow as leaves of Autumn the myriads of Angelic hosts.
Fell thro' the wintry skies seeking their graves;
Rattling their hollow bones in howling and lamentation.
Then Enitharmon woke nor knew that she had slept
And eighteen hundred years were fled
As if they had not been
She calld her sons & daughters
To the sports of night,
Within her crystal house;
And thus her song proceeds.
Arise Ethinthus! tho' the earth-worm call;
Let him call in vain;
Till the night of holy shadows
And human solitude is past!

objnote.p: This impression is in the first state (of three). In this impression of the first state, line 32 reads "She ceas'd, and all went forth to sport beneath the solemn moon" and line 35 reads "Till morning ope'd the eastern gate, and the angel trumpet blew." Object 27 (Bentley Plate 11) is printed on the recto.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This text plate contains many interlinear vines, birds, insects, and three snakes. Four butterflies appear right of lines 1-4. A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 6. Two vines grow from the first letter of the first word in line 9. Vines, at least two birds, and what may be flames decorate the space between lines 5 and 6. A butterfly and two other winged insects, two vines (one may be a worm), and an odd shape that may be two moths or bats flying close together appear between lines 8 and 9. A vine with multiple branches and leaves wends its way through the margin right of lines 8-19. From this vine, flowers shaped like Shooting Stars (Dodecatheon meadia) grow right of line 9, close to the right margin of the plate, and right of line 12, below and to the left of the first one. On and around this large vine are an inch worm (below the last word in line 8), caterpillars (above and to the right of line 14 and right of lines 9-10 and 15-16), a spider (right of line 14), and several flying insects. Five flying insects (at least one a butterfly) follow line 11. A vine with one loop descends left of the first word in line 15. A vine extends from the first letter of the first word ("My") in line 20 and another vine with two loops grows from the descender of the last letter of "thy" in the same line. A large bird, possibly an eagle, and three smaller birds or insects fly near the right margin of the plate right of lines 18-20. A vine with many loops fills the considerable space between lines 20 and 21 and descends in the right margin to line 26. On this vine are at least two large and two small caterpillars, an inch-worm, two snails, at least three spiders, at least two insects with wings folded, and a bird perched near the right margin with its mouth open. A second bird perches within the loops of the vine, nearly obscured; facing left, it stretches with mouth open toward a small worm. A large moth or butterfly appears below "Antamon" in line 20. A flying insect, possibly a dragonfly, is pictured far to the right of line 23. Below and to the left is a large bird (possibly an eagle) soaring upwards, with a flock of at least five birds to the left. The form right of lines 26-30 probably represents the sky seen through clouds formed from the negative space of the page. Small vines extend up and to the right from the first letters of the first words in lines 22, 26, and 32. A vine descends from the second letter of "my" in line 25. A vine with leaves and several branches appears right of lines 28-37. Intertwined with this vine is a snake, facing to the left with its mouth open and its forked tongue clearly pictured. Two other snakes, both facing left, appear in the bottom margin. The right-most snake in the lower margin has a clearly pictured tongue. The last letter of the last word in line 34 grows into a vine.

The space between lines 20 and 21 of the text includes two large caterpillars, an inch-worm, a small spider, and a snail. To the left of the caterpillars is a flying insect, most likely a butterfly or moth.

The space between lines 20 and 21, near the right margin, includes two spiders (one large, one small), at least two insects of uncertain species with wings folded, a caterpillar, a snail, and a bird perched on a vine, facing up and with its mouth open and probably singing. A second bird perches within the loops of the vine to the left; facing left, it stretches with mouth open toward a small worm on the nearby vine.

A snake is intertwined with the vine in the lower right corner of the plate. It faces left, with mouth open and forked tongue clearly pictured.
Two snakes appear in the lower margin. Both face left with mouths open. The tongue of the right-most snake is clearly pictured.
Several flames appear below and to the right of the last word ("Enitharmon") in line 5 of the text.
Two vines that grow from the "V" of the first word in line 6 ("Manathu-Varcyon") extend horizontally between lines 5 and 6 of the text. Both may bear slender leaves.

A vine with multiple branches and leaves wends its way through the margin right of lines 8-19 of the text. At least one flower, shaped like a Shooting Star (Dodecatheon meadia), grows close to the right margin of the plate, right of line 9. Another such flower appears below and to the left of the first one, right of line 12. A third flower may droop directly below the first blossom.

lg.l: Ethinthus queen of waters, how thou shinest in the sky:
My daughter how do I rejoice! for thy children flock around
Like the gay fishes on the wave, when the cold moon drinks the dew
Ethinthus! thou art sweet as comforts to my fainting soul;
For now thy waters warble round the feet of Enitharmon.
Manathu-Varcyon! I behold thee flaming in my halls,
Light of thy mothers soul! I see thy lovely eagles round:
Thy golden wings are my delight, & thy flames of soft delusion.
Where is my lureing bird of Eden! Leutha silent love!
Leutha. the many colourd bow delights upon thy wings;
Soft soul of flowers Leutha!
Sweet smiling pestilence! I see thy blushing light;
Thy daughters many changing,
Revolve like sweet perfumes ascending O Leutha silken queen!
Where is the youthful Antamon. prince of the pearly dew,
O Antamon, why wilt thou leave thy mother Enitharmon?
Alone I see thee crystal form.
Floting upon the bosomd air:
With lineaments of gratified desire.
My Antamon the seven churches of Leutha seek thy love,
I hear the soft Oothoon in Enitharmons tents:
Why wilt thou give up womans secrecy my melancholy child?
Between two moments bliss is ripe:
O Theotormon robb'd of joy, I see thy salt tears flow
Down the steps of my crystal house.
Sotha & Thiralatha. secret dwellers of dreamful caves,
Arise and please the horrent fiend with your melodious songs.
Still all your thunders golden hoofd, & bind your horses black.
Orc! smile upon my children!
Smile son of my afflictions.
Arise O Orc and give our mountains joy of thy red light.
She ceas'd, and all went forth to sport beneath the solemn moon.
Waking the stars of Urizen with their immortal songs,
That nature felt thro' all her pores the enormous revelry.
Till morning ope'd the eastern gate, and the angel trumpet blew.
Then every one fled to his station. & Enitharmon wept.
But terrible Orc, when he beheld the morning in the east,

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state (of three). Numbered "10" in pen and ink, top right, possibly by Blake. In this impression of the second state, line 33 reads as in the first state ("She ceas'd, and all went forth to sport beneath the solemn moon") but line 36 reads as in the third state ("Till morning op'ed the eastern gate."). Object 37 (Bentley Plate 16) is printed on the recto.

A caterpillar appears above and to the right of the ending of line 15 of the text. Further to the right on the same vine is a spider. Another caterpillar appears on the vine right of lines 16-17.

Right of line 18 of the text are two flying insects or birds. Another such creature appears near the right margin. A large bird, perhaps an eagle, flies downward right of lines 19-20. Two very small birds or winged insects appear below the bird, right of line 21.

The space between lines 21 and 22 of the text includes two large caterpillars, an inch-worm, a small spider, and a snail. To the left of the caterpillars is a flying insect, most likely a butterfly or moth.

The space between lines 21 and 22, near the right margin, includes two spiders (one large, one small), at least two insects of uncertain species with wings folded, a caterpillar, a snail, and a bird perched on a vine, facing up and with its mouth open and probably singing. A second bird perches within the loops of the vine to the left; facing left, it stretches with mouth open toward a small worm on the nearby vine.

A flock of at least five birds flies right of line 26 (what may be the sixth bird upper right is not printed clearly). Further to the right is a large bird, perhaps an eagle, soaring upwards. Above and to the right of the bird is a flying insect, perhaps a dragonfly with four wings.
A snake is intertwined with the vine in the lower right corner of the plate. It faces left, with mouth open and forked tongue clearly pictured.
Two snakes appear in the lower margin. Both face left with mouths open. The tongue of the right-most snake is clearly pictured.
Several flames appear below and to the right of the last word ("Enitharmon") in line 6 of the text.
Two vines that grow from the "V" of the first word in line 7 ("Manathu-Varcyon") extend horizontally between lines 6 and 7 of the text. Both may bear slender leaves.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 7 of the text.
Two vines spring from the first letter of the first word in line 10 of the text.
A vine—or perhaps a worm—twists above "Leutha," line 10 of the text. A second vine (or perhaps the partial outline of a cloud) extends horizontally above the last two words in the same line.

A vine with multiple branches and leaves wends its way through the margin right of lines 9-20 of the text. At least one flower, shaped like a Shooting Star (Dodecatheon meadia), grows close to the right margin of the plate, right of line 10. Another such flower appears below and to the left of the first one, right of line 13. A third flower may droop directly below the first blossom.
A vine with one loop descends from the first letter of the first word in line 16 of the text.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 21, and a vine with two loops grows from the descender of the last letter of “thy” in this line.
A vine grows from the last letter of the final word of line 35.
A large vine with many loops extends between lines 21 and 22 of the text. Some tendrils, perhaps with leaves, descend in the right margin to line 27.
A vine grows from the first letter of the first word in line 23, and from the descender of the second letter of "my" in line 26.
Small vines extend up and to the right from the first letters of the first words in lines 27, and 33.
The odd form right of lines 27-31 probably represents sky or the margins of clouds.
A vine or plant with leaves and several branches appears in the bottom margin and right of lines 29-38 of the text.

lg.l: Ethinthus queen of waters, how thou shinest in the sky:
My daughter how do I rejoice! for thy children flock around
Like the gay fishes on the wave, when the cold moon drinks the dew.
Ethinthus! thou art sweet as comforts to my fainting soul;
For now thy waters warble round the feet of Enitharmon.
Manathu-Varcyon! I behold thee flaming in my halls,
Light of thy mothers soul! I see thy lovely eagles round:
Thy golden wings are my delight, & thy flames of soft delusion.
Where is my lureing bird of Eden! Leutha silent love!
Leutha. the many colourd bow delights upon thy wings;
Soft soul of flowers Leutha!
Sweet smiling pestilence! I see thy blushing light;
Thy daughters many changing,
Revolve like sweet perfumes ascending O Leutha silken queen!
Where is the youthful Antamon. prince of the pearly dew,
O Antamon, why wilt thou leave thy mother Enitharmon?
Alone I see thee crystal form.
Floting upon the bosomd air:
With lineaments of gratified desire.
My Antamon the seven churches of Leutha seek thy love.
I hear the soft Oothoon in Enitharmons tents:
Why wilt thou give up womans secrecy my melancholy child?
Between two moments bliss is ripe:
O Theotormon robb'd of joy, I see thy salt tears flow
Down the steps of my crystal house.
Sotha & Thiralatha, secret dwellers of dreamful caves,
Arise and please the horrent fiend with your melodious songs.
Still all your thunders golden hoofd, & bind your horses black.
Orc! smile upon my children!
Smile son of my afflictions.
Arise O Orc and give our mountains joy of thy red light.
She ceas'd, and all went forth to sport beneath the solemn moon.
Waking the stars of Urizen with their immortal songs,
That nature felt thro' all her pores the enormous revelry.
Till morning ope'd the eastern gate.Line 36, as originally written, ended with "and the angel trumpet blew." These five words were removed from the copper plate.
Then every one fled to his station. & Enitharmon wept.
But terrible Orc, when he beheld the morning in the east,

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state (of three). In this impression of the second state, line 1 reads as in the first state: "Shot from the heights of Enitharmon before the trumpet blew;".

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, a nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the gowned young girl whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is her father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. We see her from behind; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left. The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a gowned woman—perhaps the child's mother. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her gown, and presumably her legs, dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying. Lower left, on top of the steps, is a fluted and broken pillar.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of three figures may be a family of mother, father, and female child.

A nude, muscular male with short, curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the young girl whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is her father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. He carries the limp body of a woman over his right shoulder, holding her around the waist with his raised and bent right arm.

We see a young gowned female child from behind. Her left arm is held by the nude male; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left.

The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a gowned woman—perhaps the child's mother. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her gown, and presumably her legs, dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying.
The background of the design below the text is composed mostly of a sheet of flames.
Three stone steps, or two steps and a plinth, and a fluted and broken classical pillar appear in the lower left corner of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area contains a good many vegetative motifs and animals. Three vines extend horizontally between lines 2 and 3. The vine on the left includes a loop and one ivy-like leaf. The next vine to the right, which extends from the horizontal descender of the "y" in "vineyards" (line 2), bears two oak or grape leaves. The largest vine, furthest to the right, has long, slender leaves. At least four insects, perhaps beetles and one caterpillar, crawl on it; there may be a fifth insect, perhaps a grasshopper, on the vine at far right. Three winged insects (some little more than dots) and one butterfly (below "fury" in line 2) fly above the vine, with three more dots that might be winged insects flying below the vine just left of the right margin. Below "of his" in line 2, a bird perches on the vine but spreads its wings as if about to fly into the air. An oak or grape leaf grows into the left margin from the first letter of the first word of line 3 ("The"). A vine with ivy-like leaves extends horizontally between lines 8 and 9, divides into several branches in the right margin, and has one branch arching back to the left at line 6. A branch bearing five oak leaves and one acorn extends into the right margin following the final line of text. To the right of this branch, a bird flies upward on extended wings. From the first letter of the first word of line 10 ("And"), a vine extends downward and almost touches the flames below. A vine with two loops grows from the first letter of "FINIS" (line 12) and extends horizontally above the word.

component.illusobjdesc: At least four insects, perhaps beetles and one caterpillar, crawl along the vine between lines 2 and 3 of the text. There may be a further insect, perhaps a grasshopper, on the vine near the right margin. Three tiny creatures (one just a dot) fly below the vine just left of the right margin.
Four winged insects (some little more than dots) fly above the vine between lines 2 and 3 of the text. The insect below "fury" at the end of line 2 is probably a butterfly.
A bird perches on the vine between lines 2 and 3 of the text, just below "of his" in line 2. Its wings spread as though it were about to fly.
A bird flies upward and to the left on extended wings near the right margin of the plate, right of the branch following the final line of text.
A vine with one loop and an ivy-like leaf grows from the first letter of the first word ("The") in line 3 of the text. An oak or grape leaf grows into the left margin from the same letter.
A vine with two oak or grape leaves grows out of the horizontal descender of the "y" in "vineyards" (line 2) and extends horizontally below line 2 of the text.
A large vine with slender leaves extends horizontally beneath line 2 of the text and descends, in the right margin, to line 10.
A large vine with ivy-like leaves extends horizontally between lines 8 and 9 of the text and divides into several branches in the right margin. One branch extends back to the left at line 6.
A branch bearing five oak leaves and one acorn extends into the right margin following the final line of text (line 12).
A vine extends downward from the first letter of the first word of line 10 ("And") and almost touches the flames below.
A vine with two loops grows from the first letter of "FINIS" (line 12) and extends horizontally above the word.

lg.l: Shot from the heights of Enitharmon, before the trumpet blew;
And in the vineyards of red France appear'd the light of his fury.
The sun glow'd fiery red!
The furious terrors flew around!
On golden chariots raging, with red wheels dropping with blood;
The Lions lash their wrathful tails!
The Tigers couch upon the prey & suck the ruddy tide;
And Enitharmon groans & cries in anguish and dismay.
Then Los arose his head he reard in snaky thunders clad:
And with a cry that shook all nature to the utmost pole,
Call'd all his sons to the strife of blood.

objnote.p: This posthumous impression is in the third state (of three). In this impression of the third state, line 1 reads "Shot from the heights of Enitharmon;".
